Award.AwardTitle: Implementation Project: Strategic Plan for the Integration of Nanotechnology in Undergraduate Programs (SPIN-UP)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project at J F Drake State Technical College builds on a very successful previous implementation project and has the goals to expand the number and diversity of STEM educational opportunities for students, to expand the number of minority, female, and first-generation students entering and completing postsecondary STEM education opportunities at Drake State, and to increase the percentage of students retained in and completing postsecondary STEM education programs at Drake State.

The project includes twelve elements to further improve the college's STEM programs and to prepare students for study at 4-year institutions and high-demand, high-wage careers in STEM. They are: nanotechnology integrated across the curriculum, development of a chemistry program, faculty professional development in nanotechnology and chemistry, interactive, 3-D visualization learning objects and a 3-D classroom for STEM courses, Summer Bridge activities emphasizing nanotechnology, summer technology camps for middle school students, a Summer Technology Institute to introduce nanotechnology to secondary school educators, a first-year student coaching program shown to be effective in raising second-year and long-term retention rates, supplemental instruction that places peer mentors and tutors in classrooms to assist faculty and students, faculty and student research projects that can be presented at conferences, virtual learning communities utilizing interconnection between the College's Blackboard Learning Management System and various social network systems, and research on the effectiveness of student coaching, supplemental instruction, and interactive, 3-D learning objects on the retention and learning outcomes of minority, female, first-generation, and economically under-resourced students. This project will prepare veterans, minorities, women, first-generation students, and economically under-resourced students for a broad range of new and exciting, high-wage, high-demand STEM careers.

Institution.Name: J F Drake State Technical College
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: J.F. DRAKE STATE COMMUNITY AND TECHNICAL COLLEGE

Performance_Institution.Name: J F Drake State Technical College

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
As outlined in the proposed activities, the College hosted a middle school technology camp for one week and a STEM Summer Bridge Camp to expand the number and diversity of STEM educational opportunities for students.

The summer bridge program (June 12, 2017 -July 7, 2017) aims to increase awareness and understanding of STEM fields and prepare students for college success, which included a tour of the campus, dual enrollment opportunities/requirements, and career-related activities. The camp consists of 3 STEM-related courses: Computer and Information Systems, Biology/Chemistry-combined, and Math/Physics-combined.  The camps included rigorous hands-on activities and used a constructivist approach to STEM learning that combined integrated coursework and practical experience.

The STEM Summer Bridge Camp participation from summer 2017 increased by 36%. A total of eighty (80) high school juniors and seniors participated in the 2017 summer bridge camp. The 2016 summer camp had a total of fifty-nine (59) participants.  39% (31) of the participants were returning participants from the 2016 summer camp. The participants for the 2017 STEM Summer Bridge camp included 33 males and 47 females. 41% (33) of the male participants were identified as minorities, and 53% (42) of the female participants were identified as minorities (Appendix 1).

The participants completed a pre-survey titled “High School Students Attitude Towards STEM.”   A total of 74 surveys were completed during the first day of summer camp. The remaining six were unidentified.  The survey revealed 51.35% strongly viewed science as a Fascinating subject and 1.37% strongly viewed it as a Boring subject.  24.66% strongly viewed math as a Fascinating subject, and 8.11% strongly viewed the subject as Boring (Appendix 2).

The survey also discovered 87.84% of the participants planned on attending a four-year college after completing high school and only 9.46% of the participants were interested in attending a two-year college and 5.41% were interested in attending a career training program (Appendix 2).  This could be an indication that the participants are unaware of the opportunities and advantages of attending a two-year college. The post-survey will determine if the summer program had any influence on their views of science and math and planned after graduating high school. The post-survey will not be completed until the end of camp (July 6, 2017).

The College continues to integrate nanotechnology in the undergraduate courses, particularly in Biology and Math. Engineering Graphic department is looking to graphene in the 3D curriculum.

Biology Nanotechnology:
To better prepare our student for life and the new challenges they will face in this rapidly evolving technological world, general studies have integrated nanotechnology studies into our curriculum.  In our General Biology classes, students learn about the science of everything from small-macro organism biological and cellular structures.  General concepts of the difference between the micro world and the nano-world are reviewed.

Mathematics:
For mathematic, there were more supportive activities implemented to assist with the Biology project and course work as indicated.  Students have an opportunity to engaged in activities that related to math and physics properties and concepts that overlapped in the biology and chemistry. 
There was a total of 111 students reported during the 2015-2016 academic year. During the 2016-2017 academic year, there was a 74% (193 students) increase in the number students enrolled in a STEM field:

(CIS) Computer and Information Systems (98 students-51%)
(DDT) Engineering Graphics (24 students-12%)
(EET) Electrical Engineering (35 students-19%)
(MTT) Machine Tool Technology (36 students-19%)

47 (24%)of the students enrolled in a STEM-related field were females. 72% (34) were considered minorities. 146 males were enrolled in a STEM field, and 47% (69) were identified as minorities.

A tested term to term report was analyzed to obtain the retention data. Between spring 2016 and spring 2017, a total of 375 students were retained. There were 248 (66%) minorities retained, but only 35 (14%) were in a STEM-related field. 43% of the 35 had a 2.5 and above GPA.

CIS (54%)
DDT (14%)
EET (26%)
MTT (6%)

Overall, the number of students being retained in STEM programs has increased by 39% from the last reporting period. 146 students were reported as being retained between spring 2015 and spring 2016.  

Peer and Professional Tutors/Mentors were hired to tutor and mentor students enrolled specifically in STEM courses. The College also hired two student success coaches to assist with retention efforts.

In attempts to retain students and ensure completion, the student coaches worked alongside with the Enrollment Service Manager/STEM Coordinator as well as the College Counselor to contact students concerning their attendance and academics.

The STEM Coordinator/Enrollment Service Manager will follow-up and track the summer bridge participants and encourage them to enroll in the college as a full-time or dual enrollment student. The College will continue to practice the initiatives that were implemented during the 2016-2017 academic year and will request a no-cost extension to continue these efforts.

 

 


Last Modified: 06/28/2017
Modified by: Khalid Holmes
